title: Nearly half of British toddlers tried a crisp before they had tasted cabbage
text:

Almost half of British toddlers tried a crisp before they ever tasted a cabbage, alarming new research shows.

Stressed parents told today how they'd prefer they'd children had a more varied diet.

But in a new drive to help parents, the world’s first "Pram Drive Thru" was created to help educate parents and youngsters on how healthy food can be convenient and fun.

It comes as surprising data highlights 47% of British parents say their toddler tried a crisp before they had tasted cabbage.

And nearly a sixth (16%) of British children had eaten pizza before peas.

"Encouraging little ones to try new veggie tastes during weaning is no easy task as our research shows, but it can be made a little easier by experimenting with new flavours.

(Image: PA)

"It can take up to eight tries for little ones’ tiny taste buds to learn to accept the taste of all types of veg, so trying different cooking ways can make the adventure a little more fun," Mark Cuddigan, SEO of organic baby food brand Ella's Kitchen.

Other research from the baby food brand shows;

31% of parents said they don’t have time to experiment in the kitchen to help gibe their children a varied diet

60% of parents said that their under-5-year-old is a fussy eater

Seven in ten (70%) admit their toddlers do not get enough greens in their diet

Four fifths (80%) of Brits find the weaning stage incredibly stressful, in terms of making sure their kids got all the nutrients they needed

Three in five British parents wish they introduced veg to their children earlier on

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

Mr Cuddigan added: "Pram Drive Thru is a great way of us showing how we are always here with new ways to support families on their wonderful weaning journey and help to make it a fun and yummy experience for both little ones and their parents."

Pram Drive Thru comes after the nationwide poll of 1,500 British parents of under-fives children explored the many reasons parents struggle to introduce veg into their little one’s diet.

It showed just 31% of parents said they just don’t have time to experiment in the kitchen.

Most vegetables can be baked, roasted, pureed and mashed but mums and dads say they typically only cook the likes of broccoli, squash and cauliflower two different ways at most.

description: Parents of under-fives told about the stresses of feeding their children vegetables in new research commissioned by Ella's Kitchen
